explanation: The correct answer requires identifying a shape with two congruent triangular bases connected by three rectangular lateral faces, maintaining a uniform triangular cross-section throughout its length. The student likely observed a shape containing triangular elements (such as triangular faces) but misidentified which faces constitute the cross-section. Their error stems from conflating lateral faces with the defining base shape, leading them to select a shape where triangles appear in non-cross-section faces. This directly aligns with confusing face types rather than misunderstanding cross-section uniformity or cylindrical properties. The mistake differs from simply focusing on rectangular faces because triangular elements were present but misattributed.
